description: Learn more about ASTRAGALUS uses, effectiveness, possible side effects, interactions, dosage, user ratings and products that contain ASTRAGALUS.
cleaned_text: Overview [Astragalus](https://www.webmd.com/heart/astragalus-root-heart-benefits-side-effects)(Astragalus membranaceus) is a type of flowering plant. The root has been used for centuries in traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM). Astragalus is considered an adaptogen. Adaptogens are a class of natural substances that are believed to stimulate the body's resistance to physical, environmental, and emotional stressors. The chemicals in astragalus also seem to stimulate the [immune system](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/immune-system-function)and reduce swelling. People commonly use astragalus for [hay fever](https://www.webmd.com/allergies/rhinitis), diabetes, [kidney disease](https://www.webmd.com/a-to-z-guides/understanding-kidney-disease-basic-information), and many other conditions, but there is no good scientific evidence to support these uses. There is also no good evidence to support using astragalus for COVID-19. There are many species of astragalus. Some species contain a nerve toxin and have been linked to livestock poisonings. These include Astragalus lentiginosus, Astragalus mollissimus, and others. But [dietary supplements](https://www.webmd.com/vitamins-and-supplements/supplement-faq). Most don't confuse astragalus with tragacanth. These are different plants. Uses & Effectiveness ? Possibly Effective for - Reducing [side effects of chemotherapy](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/tips-for-managing-chemotherapy-side-effects). Early research suggests that giving astragalus intravenously (by IV) or using Chinese herbal mixtures containing astragalus might reduce nausea, [vomiting](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-nausea-vomiting), [diarrhea](https://www.webmd.com/digestive-disorders/digestive-diseases-diarrhea), and [bone marrow](https://www.webmd.com/heart/anatomy-picture-of-blood)suppression (a decrease in the cells that provide [immunity](https://www.webmd.com/cold-and-flu/10-immune-system-busters-boosters)) that is associated with [chemotherapy](https://www.webmd.com/cancer/chemotherapy-what-to-expect)treatments. - Diabetes. Early research suggests that astragalus, given intravenously (by IV) or taken by [mouth](https://www.webmd.com/oral-health/ss/slideshow-mouth-problems)as a combination product, might help control [blood sugar](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/how-sugar-affects-diabetes)and [insulin](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/diabetes-types-insulin)levels in people with [type 2 diabetes](https://www.webmd.com/diabetes/type-2-diabetes). But some research in animals suggests that it can be toxic during pregnancy and to the [fetus](https://www.webmd.com/parenting/baby/ss/slideshow-baby-milestones-first-year). Stay on the safe side and avoid use. "Auto-immune system conditions: Astragalus might make the immune system more active. This could worsen the symptoms of auto-immune diseases. Avoid using astragalus if you have any of these conditions. Interactions ? Cyclophosphamide interacts with ASTRAGALUS Cyclophosphamide is used to make the immune system less active. Astragalus increases the activity of the immune system. Taking astragalus along with cyclophosphamide might decrease the effects of cyclophosphamide. Medications that decrease the immune system (Immunosuppressants) interacts with ASTRAGALUS Astragalus can increase the activity of the immune system. Some medications, such as those used after a transplant, decrease the activity of the immune system. Taking astragalus along with these medications might decrease the effects of these medications. Lithium interacts with ASTRAGALUS Taking astragalus might decrease how well the body gets rid of lithium. This could increase how much lithium is in the body and result in serious side effects. Talk with your healthcare provider before using this product if you are taking lithium. Your lithium dose might need to be changed.
